title: ORA performance HTTP

labels.name: RIA/ORA
labels.description: Issues related to RIA-based workflows and related components

body:
With PR #4561 HTTP support is introduced for ORA special remote. There appears to be a huge per-file delay (see @mih's reporting in that PR). While Michael reported an overall bandwith of ~20MB/s, I think bandwith is not a useful description. Running a local apache server, I get within-file bandwith of easily above 600MB/s. But I see the same per-file overhead leading to rediculous "perceived" bandwith when using tons of small files. Running some analysis here based on the same dataset I used in #4563 for testing performance on local FS.


CHECKPRESENT profile

![output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10498301/83007252-b7669e80-a013-11ea-917a-3dbe0f5f7f03.png)

TRANSFER profile

![output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10498301/83008172-14168900-a015-11ea-9dfb-45a10bf8e4c3.png)


`git annex get --debug`:

```
...
[2020-05-27 12:26:19.319279954] git-annex-remote-ora[1] <-- TRANSFER RETRIEVE MD5E-s6--f858ca775796efe8052f179dae5224e4.txt .git/annex/tmp/MD5E-s6--f858ca775796efe8052f179dae5224e4.txt
[2020-05-27 12:26:19.319577707] git-annex-remote-ora[1] --> DIRHASH MD5E-s6--f858ca775796efe8052f179dae5224e4.txt
[2020-05-27 12:26:19.31964529] git-annex-remote-ora[1] <-- VALUE 3M/f7/
[2020-05-27 12:26:19.354892578] git-annex-remote-ora[1] --> PROGRESS 6
100%  6 B               167 B/s 0s[2020-05-27 12:26:19.355242702] git-annex-remote-ora[1] --> TRANSFER-SUCCESS RETRIEVE MD5E-s6--f858ca775796efe8052f179dae5224e4.txt
(checksum...) ok                  
...
```

Wireshark timestamps:

![Screenshot_20200527_124041](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10498301/83009659-5c36ab00-a017-11ea-8090-6dd33e340291.png)


To me it seems those pieces above make it abundantly clear that we are indeed just waiting for the server to deliver. I can't see anything we can do about that clients-side (within ORA implementation). However, using this issue to further investigate what's the problem server-side.
